[Mapa]
CROFT HISTORIES No 1

Balranald and Paiblesgarry were never actually owned by any of the MacDonalds but merely leased from their Sleat superiors until in 1894 it was brought by Alexander MacDonald ( Ailig Bhaile Raghnaill ) for £8 , 000 .

Prior to this his father , James MacDonald , ( Seumas Ruadh ) , had tenanted Paiblesgarry and Balranald . He had most of the land to himself except for cottars ’ houses which were usually sited on the most unproductive land , e . g . Druimdubh . A sore point with Seumas Ruadh was the fact that on one of the most fertile spots in Paiblesgarry was a cottar ’ s house . This house belonged to William MacDonald , ( son of Angus , son of John , son of Alexander ) . His wife Christina ( died 1853 ) was from Skye and worked at Balranald as a servant . Seumas Ruadh called at William ’ s house one day where Christina was nursing a son to whom she had recently - given birth . ‘ Balranald ’ asked what the boy ’ s name was , but he was told that this had not been decided yet . ‘ Balranald ’ suggested that it would be to their advantage to call the boy James , after himself . A bargain of coercion was struck there and then , the boy was named James , and as a reward James and hi older brother Angus were to be granted tenancy of neighbouring crofts in Knockintorran , ( Nos 11 and 12 , immediately “ over the wall ” from Paiblesgarry . William and his family subsequently moved to Knockintorran thus leaving Paiblesgarry as a clean tack , cottars excluded of course . ‘ Balranald ’ had to evict two families from Knockintorran to make way for William and his family .

Alexander , who succeeded his father Seumas Ruadh , was helped by a grieve and servants who lived in tied houses in Paiblesgarry . On the machair , at the boundary of Paiblesgarry and Balranald , stood
‘ Tigh a ’ Mhachaire ’
. The last tenant was John MacDonald ( Iain Mac Aonghais Bhig ) . His main duty was to ensure that no stray sheep or cattle from Knockintorran were to wander on to Paiblesgarry . If that did happen , he would drive them along to Balranald and impound them till the owner called to collect them and paid the ‘ impounding fee ’ . This was demanded as late as 1950 .

One of Alexander ’ s most prominent farm managers was John MacLean ( Seonaidh Mac Iain Oig ) and much credit must be given to him for the running of the Estate . His father was a grieve and came from Sleat .

His only son , Ronald , who succeeded him , had however a totally·different upbringing having been sent at an early age to the south . He spoke with a short clipped English accent thus segregating himself unintentionally from the islanders . Ronald was not a farmer like his father , but followed a career in the army , rising to the rank of captain in the late 1920s . Known as Raghnall Mor , he was a good looking tall man who never married and who never managed to integrate into a crofting society . To a simple people his father ’ s title of
‘ Fear a ’ Bhaile ’
was far more congenial than ‘ Captain MacDonald ’ .

There was a general election imminent . ·Some of us went to a·meeting in Bayhead School , where the Liberal M . P . - a Dr . Murray_ was present . After the meeting we met him and told him of our dissatisfaction with our enquiries for land . He told us vehemently that we would never acquire a plot of land unless we raided it .

There was : Roderick MacDonald ( Ruairidh Iain Mhic Ruairidh ) , Knockline , 32 years ; Norman Laing ( Tormod Lionc ) , Balemore , 50 years ; Donald E . MacDonald ( Domhnall Eoghainn Aonghais Bhig ) , Balemore , 22 years ; Alex . MacRury ( Ailig Iain Bhig ) , Balemore , 32 years ; Donald MacDonald ( Domhnall Dhomhnaill Eoghainn ) , Balemore , 23 years ; Donald Matheson ( Domhnall Eoghainn Dhomhnaill Bhain ) , Knockintorran , 32 years ; Alasdair MacDonald ( Alasdair Mac Iain ) , Knockintorran , 32 years ; Archibald Ferguson ( Gilleasbuig Iain Mhic Fhearghuis ) , Knockintorran , 30 years ; John Alick MacAulay ( Seonaidh Ailig Neill ) , Knockintorran , 24 years ; Ewen MacLean ( Eoghainn Thormoid ) , Balemore , 36 years ; John MacDonald ( Iain an Eilean ) , Knockintorran , 48 years ; Angus MacAulay ( Aonghas Ailig an t - Saoir ) , Balemore , 24 years .

The following day Captain MacDonald - Raghnall Mor - started seaweeding along with his servants . On filling their carts , we approached them and overturned all the carts . I remember distinctly that it was Gilleasbuig Mac Raghnaill ’ s cart I overturned . Gilleasbuig , who had a son who had been to war , was sympathetic and said to me , ‘ Well done ’ . Maybe the other servants of Balranald were not so sympathetic as Gilleasbuig in seeing ‘ Balranald ’ beaten that day .

Soon we were taken out to the wide corridor outside our cells , where I noticed Norman Laing , one of the raiders , who , being of a small stature , did not look at my face and certainly did not recognise me in my prison garb . He turned to Donald Ewen MacDonald and said , “ Look at this Irishman beside me . Nach ann air a tho coltas an uamhais ” . Donald went into convulsions . Norman Laing had a second look at me , and gazing at my garb asked , “ Where in the name of creation did you get that outfit ? ” I replied , “ You wait , tomorrow you will have the same attire yourself ! ” If it was possible for one to get a weekly change of clothes one could keep one ’ s own clothing , but in this situation that was impossible for all of us .

Eventually a letter arrived from our lawyer for us stating that the raided land was going to be ours . “ Cha b ’ e ruith ach leum !
” Arrangements for our release were in progress .
[Dealbh]

Fhad ’ s a bhios an linn seo beò ,
Bith cuimhn ’ air cainnteanas Lloyd George ,
Gheall e fearann do na seòid ,
Ach na thill beò dhiubh ’ s mor an gearain .

Nuair a thuig na gillean còir ,
Gun robh ’ n government fo sgleò ,
Nach robh cainnteanas Lloyd George ,
Ach mar cheò a ’ falbh a sealladh .

Aonghas Ailig an t - Saoir concluded his narrative on the Balranald raids with these words , “ The land no longer was Raghnall Mor ’ s . Was it not from a poor people his predecessors had taken it in the first place ? ” According to oral tradition poverty indeed they had been reduced to .

The Lordship of the Isles did not last . Internal and external pressures began to work on it . Clan Donald became disunited and the aforementioned Lord of the Isles , Earl of Ross , had to surrender all his titles and lands in 1493 . His lands went to the Crown and Sleat became leaseholders and were no longer owners . This continued until the Balranald Raiders had their say - Na Gillean Grinn , who reclaimed the land of their fathers .

[Dealbh]

Before the present house was built there was a thatched house on this croft , which was said to have been built around 1880 . This house went on fire and the roof had to be replaced . All the local people helped to replace the roof . The present house was built in 1939 by Angus MacAulay ( Aonghas Ailig an t - Saoir ) , Paiblesgarry . In 1964 it was extended by Angus MacKenzie ( Aonghas Mhic Anndra ) , Hougharry . The area on which this house is built is called Druim na h - Uamha ( Ridge of the Cave ) . At one point contractors decided to excavate here , but on finding crockery and bones they decided to come to a halt .
The croft is bordered on one side by Loch a ’ Mhaoir .

This croft house was built in 1932 by Domhnaill Iain Lachlainn Thailleir ( Donald John MacDonald ) , Sollas . The house was extensively renovated in the early 1980s by Roderick MacCuish ( Ruairidh Alasdair a ’ Ruaidh ) , Claddach Kirkibost .

Domhnall Eoghainn Aonghais Bhig
( Balemore )

Catriona Chalum Mhoir Eoghainn Alasdair
( Hougharry )
There are three houses joined together which before 1921 were used by Balranald servants . Two of the inhabitants were Donnchadh Eubhal and Seumas Orasaidh .
[Dealbh]

Seonaidh Sgoileir was the only tenant of this croft . After his departure the croft was cultivated by several people . One of them was Seumas a ’ Ghobha of Hougharry . Shortly afterwards the Department of Agriculture took over the land and it was divided among the remaining tenants of Balranald .

Ewen MacLean ( 1883 - 1971 )
Eoghainn Thormoid Eoghainn
( Balemore )
M .
Catherine MacDonald ( 1884 - 1952 )
Ceit Anna Aonghais Bhig
( Balemore )

The present croft house incorporates a small part of the foundation of a former building , which had been a joiner ’ s workshop and byre , belonging to Balranald Estate . ( The last joiner was Alasdair Dhomhnaill , Hougharry ) . The house was built in 1931 by Angus MacAulay ( Aonghas Ailig an t - Saoir ) , Paiblesgarry . In 1951 , the tenant , Ewen MacLean , built an extension . Places of interest on this croft are Loch na Cille and Loch na Ceardaich .
[Dealbh]
[Dealbh]

Donald Matheson ( 1885 - 1983 )
Domhnall Eoghainn ’ ic Dhomhnaill Bhain
( Knockintorran )
M .
Mary MacKiggan ( South Uist )

Domhnall Iain Alasdair a ’ Mhuilleir
Nighean Dhomhnaill Bhain Lachlainn
( Baleshare )

In 1921 , after the land raids , a zinc - roofed house was built on this croft . The present house was built by Angus MacAulay ( Aonghas Ailig an t - Saoir ) , Paiblesgarry , in 1935 . An extension was built by John MacAulay ( Seonaidh Eoghainn Sheonaidh ) , Bayhead , m 1986 . Donald Matheson left Balranald in 1950 when Donald John MacDonald ( Domhnall Iain Alasdair a ’ Mhuilleir ) became tenant .

The present house was built in 1927 by Angus MacDonald ( Aonghais Mac Iain Mhoir ) , Claddach Kirkibost . On completion of the house it was suggested that it should be called “ Tigh na Buaile ” . This was where ‘ Balranald ’ had one of his folds for his cattle .
Extensions were made in the 1970s by Roderick MacCuish ( Ruairidh Alasdair a ’ Ruaidh ) , Claddach Kirkibost .
[Dealbh]

Prior to the present house on the croft was a thatched house which was built in 1902 . Gilleasbuig Mac Raghnaill , who was a servant at Balranald lived in this house . The present house was built by Norman MacDonald ( Tormod Ban ) , Sollas , in 1954 . Extensions were made by Roderick MacDonald ( Ruairidh Aonghais Ailein ) , Sollas .

[Dealbh]

This thatched house was built for Balranald workers . Its first occupant may have been Donald MacPherson , who was a grieve at Balranald . The last Balranald servant to occupy it was Seumas Orasaidh ( James MacDonald ) , of No . 2 Balranald .
Ruins to the south of this croft were referred to as Tobhtaichean Iain Stiubhart .

Donald Gillies
M .
Lexie MacLellan
Leacsaidh Ghilleasbuig Thormoid
( Balemore )
Behind the house was Finlay MacCuish ’ s house , ( Fionnlaigh Aonghais Iain ) , who was a grieve at Balranald until 1911 . He was married to Mairead Iain Mhic Aonghais , Hougharry .

Donald John MacDonald
M . l
Marion MacDonald
Morag Ruairidh Iain Mhic Ruairidh
( 4 Paiblesgarry )

The house was built in 1923 by Angus MacDonald ( Aonghas Dhomhnaill Mhic Lachlainn ) , Bayhead . An extension was built in the 1930s by Donald MacDonald and a further extension was built by Norman MacDonald ( Tormod Ban ) , Sollas , in the 1950s .

Crossing part of the croft was a dry - stone dyke
‘ Garadh Choinnich ’
, from which a lot of stones were taken for the building of the croft house and byre . Separating this croft from No . 1 is a long ditch known as Treana Sheilich .
[Dealbh]

The first house , a thatched house , was built in the 1920s by Roderick MacDonald . Roderick was one of the land raiders . The present house was built in 1940 by Angus MacAulay ( Aonghas Ailig an t - Saoir ) , Paiblesgarry . In 1979 an extension was built by Donald John Morrison , Lochportain .
[Dealbh]

Angus MacCuish ( 1884 - 1973 )
Aonghais Fhionnlaigh Aonghais Iain
( Paiblesgarry )
M .
Margaret MacDonald ( 1885 - 1953 )
Nighean Alasdair Mhic Ruairidh
( Hougharry )
This house was built for Balranald estate workers . Prior to 1921 Aonghas Mac Alasdair Bhig and his wife Raghnaid Ruadh occupied the house . Angus succeeded Finlay MacCuish as grieve at Balranald .

Some of the landmarks on this croft include Cnoc an Uire , Cnoc na Fhucadair , and Leathad an t - Sabhail . Behind the house was one of the Balranald Estate yards . It is said that sixty people were engaged in this yard in one day at hay - making . The workers were there to work their share for getting bulls wintered at Balranald .
[Dealbh]

This house was built post - 1921 , by Donald MacDonald , Coruna . An extension was made by Angus MacAulay ( Aonghais Ailig an t - Saoir ) . The croft house was sold by John MacDonald , 4 Paiblesgarry , to Mr . Robin Murray , the present owner , who extensively renovated it .
‘ Gearraidh nan Càrnan ’
is a landmark on this croft .

The first house on this land was a cottar ’ s house - Uilleam Mac Aonghais Mhic Iain - See page 7 . The first croft house was Alick MacRury ’ s , after 1921 . Alick was one of the land raiders . The house was built by Ailig Ciobair .
In 1964 a bungalow was built by Norman MacDonald ( Tormod Ban ) , Sollas , and the ole croft house was converted into a barn / byre . An extension was made in the 1970s by Donald John Morrison , Lochportain .

[Dealbh]

The first house was built by Lachlan MacLean ( Lachlainn Mac Ailein ) , Claddach Knockline , in 1922 . John , the first occupant , was a land raider . An extension was built by Angus MacAulay ( Aonghais Ailig an t - Saoir ) , Paiblesgarry , in 1932 . In 1968 a further extension was built by Donald MacCorquodale , Benbecula . It is inhabited by Archie and Catherine MacCorquodale .
[Dealbh]

James Alexander Ronald MacDonald
( Raghnall Mor )
N . M .

After 1921 , Raghnall Mor was left with Gearraidh an Fhidhleir , and the area around his house . He maintained his dominance but mostly over youngsters who intruded the garden for apples , or over trespassers seeking lapwings ’ eggs on his now diminished acreage .
TIGH AIG CNOC A ’ GHUNNA
Cnoc a ’ Ghunna , the Hill of the Gun , got its name from a gun salvaged from a ship that was wrecked at Bogha Bhrocaid , - near Hanglam , off Balranald machair .

CIDSIN DUBH
The Cidsin Dubh or the Black Kitchen was built several hundred yards away from Balranald House . It was here that the servants dined . Two families occupied this house at the same time .

JESSIE OF BALRANALD - SEASAIDH BHAILE RAGHNAILL

One of the most well known stories regarding Balranald House is that of the elopement of Jessie Catherine MacDonald of Balranald , North Uist , and Donald MacDonald of Monkstadt , Skye . Jessie was one of six daughters of James Thomas MacDonald of Lynedale , Skye , and Balranald , North Uist . Seumas Ruadh , as he was known , was factor of North Uist at that time . Jessie ’ s mother was Jane , daughter of Captain MacKenzie of Hartfield . Donald was a son of Hugh Peter MacDonald of Monkstadt , Skye , and who was closely connected to the MacDonalds of Sleat .

Jessie and Donald first met and fell in love in Skye where Seumas Ruadh was factor for Lord MacDonald . Although Donald ’ s family was well - off , as a younger son in a family of eleven he had no immediate prospects of gaining prominence in any sphere – something which Seumas Ruadh desired in a suitor for his daughter .

When Seumas Ruadh and his family moved to North Uist , Jessie was forbidden to see Donald , but they however managed to stay in touch through Jessie ’ s maid who was from Skye . Seumas Ruadh was factor in North Uist until in 1849 he temporarily gave up his position . It was Donald of Monkstadt who was brought to Uist to take up his position . While factor he visited the MacDonald home and saw Jessie often .

During his time a new Chamberlain was appointed - a Patrick Cooper from the East coast of Scotland . He had cause to visit the home of Seumas Ruadh frequently , where he fell in love with Jessie and wanted to marry her . Jessie ’ s parents were pleased with such a match for their daughter . Cooper and Jessie ’ s parents realised that Donald was still a candidate and thus dismissed him as factor . Seumas Ruadh resumed factorship . Despite Jessie ’ s protestations , wedding arrangements for her to marry Cooper commenced .

At this time two of the Balranald maid servants were Lexie MacDonald , Carinish , and Mary Ferguson , Knockintorran . Having been informed by Jessie of her plans , it was probably why , with their assistance , the first stage of Jessie ’ s elopement was so successful . Mary Ferguson ’ s young brother Angus was sent as a lookout on that night by Seumas Ruadh .
Was this suspicion on his part that something sinister was going on or was it the usual procedure to have a sentry on nights of celebration . When the Skyemen arrived at Balranald House they gagged and bound young Angus - he may have been expecting them .
Latterly Donald and Jessie sadly separated . Jessie died at her home ‘ Hartfield ’ in 1896 . Memories of Seasaidh Bhaile Raghnaill live on in story and song .
[Dealbh]
[Dealbh]

August 3

SEUMAS DÒMHNULLACH FEAR BHAILE RÀGHAILL
ORAN DO SHEASAIDH BHAILE RÀGHAILL

Nuair·fhuair an Eliza , Seasaidh air bòrd ,
’ S ann oirre bha ’ n sgoinn ’ s iad a ’ haoisteadh nan seòl ,
Bha muir air gach taobh dhi a ’ sgaoileadh mu bòrd ,
’ S bha ’ n fhairge cho aotram ri faoileig air lòn .

Written by Rev . John Norman MacDonald , Minister of Harris ( d . 1868 ) in the name of the Minister of North Uist , Rev . Dr . Donald MacDonald ( Maighstir Dòmhnall ) , whom he reckoned was in love with Jane MacDonald , Balranald .
